tweets.text: Hi there, my name is @ramonvictor, I'm a Front-End Dev @ @bookingcom. I'm Brazilian and I work with web since 2008.  I'm excited to be here!
@operatino sorry, I thought the re-tweet of the question would expose the replies already. Thanks for the heads up.
https://t.co/O0gojEH37U https://t.co/O0gojEH37U

quoted_status.text:
.@LocalSourceNL Hi Ramon! Tell us how did you started doing web development

https://t.co/Ctq9eWgq5M

tweets.text: So, back in 2007 I enrolled in a Web Design university course. My expectations were around becoming a Designer.
However, when I started having classes about JavaScript/CSS/HTML I was like "Wow, this is cool!". So, I fell in love with front-end! :)
Only a few months later I realized that Front-End Dev was an emerging field. So, I started to play around with some pet projects.
Then, around mid 2008 I started my first part-time job as a Front-end Developer. Since then I never stopped studying. :)
It might sound cliche, but if you'd ask what Front-end Development means to me, I'd say, making money by doing what I love. :)

Yes, I finished Web Design course in 2009. I kept studying while working part-time.

https://t.co/UV5EBC3CCW https://t.co/UV5EBC3CCW

quoted_status.text: @LocalSourceNL Have you ever finished Web Design course after that? :)

tweets.text: It's funny that later in 2011 I enrolled in a sort of "master" course in "Information Design". I also finished that mid 2012.

If you had asked me that question 4 years ago, I'd say: "I'm a Designer who codes".
https://t.co/VikMxIYGZ2 https://t.co/VikMxIYGZ2

quoted_status.text: @LocalSourceNL So you feel yourself more as a designer who codes, or as an engineer who designs? :) or you don’t de design anymore?

tweets.text: Nowadays I'm more towards a Front-End Engineer with strong UX design background.
The truth is, I love the connection between Design, Code and Business.

This week’s schedule:
1. Frameworks/libraries
2. JS Modules
3. General JS best practices
4. Open source projects

We have quite a lot of in-house libraries. 
But, we do use open source projects.
https://t.co/0X3k6HufMh https://t.co/0X3k6HufMh

quoted_status.text: @LocalSourceNL So, tell us, which frameworks and libraries you use at Booking?

tweets.text: There are some teams experimenting with Redux (the actual 2kb library, instead of our own implementation).
Some devs are using morphdom (https://t.co/7viruC7D24) to render template changes.
On partner facing products, we have developers using: React, Angular and other popular frameworks.

Most part of our CSS is written in vanilla, but we do have two or three products using SASS.
https://t.co/FawwZVZkkl https://t.co/FawwZVZkkl

quoted_status.text: @LocalSourceNL Do you use people use Vanilla CSS or #Sass or @PostCSS ?

tweets.text:
Curious about Front-End Development at @bookingcom? Check out the slides of this presentation I gave recently:
https://t.co/iDwxggAdfe

This is a big challenge on the main website. Reasons in the following tweet.
https://t.co/C6W8Ldu7Vc https://t.co/C6W8Ldu7Vc

quoted_status.text: @LocalSourceNL It happens that different teams use different libs, right? How do you manage the overhead with client side scripts?

tweets.text: First reason: our codebase is quite old. Secondly, we have 70+ front-end developers in the company.
So, we only add new libs when really necessary. If we decide to adopt a new lib, we also need to communicate that with our JS community.
Unfortunately, this presentation was not recorded. 😞 https://t.co/cIXEKBmkMV
We try to figure out common pain points in our community and based on that we create standards company-wide. https://t.co/SscJkvDOyE

quoted_status.text: @LocalSourceNL nobody tries to standardize the approaches? Or they do, buts its hard to manage?

tweets.text: We don't use @PostCSS JS modules, but we do have autoprefixer included in our concatenation process. https://t.co/ThlhRhuwxd

quoted_status.text: @LocalSourceNL you don't apply @PostCSS to most of the styles? (At least autoprefixer) @jitendravyas

tweets.text: HTML/CSS are required for Designer positions at @bookingcom. So, they usually have pretty solid knowledge. https://t.co/IrVF93mKni

quoted_status.text: @LocalSourceNL I heard that Web Designers code HTML/CSS at Booking, does somebody teaches them internally to use SASS, PostCSS and etc?

tweets.text: Yes, of course. For instance, we've already done a training on basic JS programming for Designers. https://t.co/xCYsG2JXe5

quoted_status.text: @LocalSourceNL but as you said yourself, you always need to learn, and advanced things require some guidance  @bookingcom

tweets.text:
This week I've re-written a module to make impure functions pure. Here's a good reading on the topic. Thoughts?
https://t.co/od6hzPaAh5
I've started to pay more attention to pure vs impure when I started to learn #redux, because by design reducers should always be pure.
Thanks for the link. I will check it out! https://t.co/4LCWXMvr2y

quoted_status.text: @LocalSourceNL Stylelint is a second plugin to apply after Autoprefixer https://t.co/1z8FxxS2rj

tweets.text: We have a QA team and during deployment we run some automated tests with selenium. #PlanetBooking https://t.co/hLBK5Fi9jI

quoted_status.text: @LocalSourceNL do you have QAs? Which tolls do they use?

tweets.text:
One topic I forgot to mention on this week's schedule:
5. Front-End Development at @PlanetBooking

I will tag my answers with #PlanetBooking
We have an automation team. They write tests for successful experiments as well as critical features. #PlanetBooking https://t.co/tsst6Yq79h

quoted_status.text: @LocalSourceNL Who writes the selenium tests? Developers, or special automation team?

tweets.text: We had some successful A/B test experiments improving our markup for accessibility purposes. #PlanetBooking https://t.co/igmjkcnG28

quoted_status.text: @LocalSourceNL At @PlanetBooking do you care about accessibility in your websites and apps?

tweets.text: We expect that our developers already think about code markup and accessibility when building new features. #PlanetBooking
From time to time we revisit some important pages and try to optimize possible accessibility issues. #PlanetBooking
We don't have any strict process for that, so I'd say we have some room for improvement on the accessibility topic. #PlanetBooking
Yes, we also do A/A testing. Specially when we need to understand user behaviour on the page. https://t.co/PORWq2qBCR

quoted_status.text: @LocalSourceNL at @PlanetBooking do your teammates also try A/A testing?

tweets.text: @jitendravyas are you familiar with A/A testing concept?
Yes, we care about #webperf, our Principal Front-End Dev (@dicode) is the evangelist of this topic. #PlanetBooking https://t.co/d82e4ab0W6

quoted_status.text: @LocalSourceNL What about #webperf? do you care about for rendering and network performance and data cost? @PlanetBooking

tweets.text: He's always looking into different approaches of improving our site performance. As you can imagine, this is a never ending project. :)
We have our own internal translation infrastructure (front-end and backend). We need to have 100% control on that. https://t.co/ud5bRF0UfG

quoted_status.text: @LocalSourceNL How do you handle multilingual content? Do you use any templating framework?

tweets.text: Why? Because of business needs and because we need to support 42 languages. #PlanetBooking
We have Copywriters spread across IT teams. We also have lang. specialists working on translations. #PlanetBooking https://t.co/vpPA4T89JB

quoted_status.text: @LocalSourceNL is the actually content usually typed by UX designer or front-end developer in all language or by some other team?

tweets.text: Designers and developers collaborate with Copywriters to agree on the UX of the features we create. #PlanetBooking
